): Penalties appearing in a statutory notice of deﬁciency (SNOD) as a result of programs such as the AUR will fall within the exception for penalties automatically calculated through electronic means if the taxpayer does not submit any response to the notice proposing a penalty. The taxpayer’s request states the interest she earned on un- registered, publicly offered long-term bonds issued by a state government is exempt from federal income tax by the
th Amendment to the Constitution. The Supreme Court has held that it is not unconstitutional for Congress to tax such interest

(see South Carolina v. Baker, 485 U.S. 505, 108 S. Ct. 1355, 99 L. Ed. 2d 592 (1988)). Even though this is not a “speciﬁed frivolous position” listed in Notice 2010-33, it is well-settled that such interest is taxable. This position demonstrates the taxpayer’s desire to impede the administration of taxes. the taxpayer is aware of the Supreme Court decision before disregarding the position or hearing request.

, it is frivolous and shows a desire to delay or impede federal tax administration.
